Barton, Former Board Chairman, Dies
Was Trustee For Six
University Presidents
Carlyle Barton, Sr., 76, retired chairman of the Board of
Trustees of the Johns Hopkins University and prominent Baltimore
attorney, died Monday morning, March 5 at his home, 16 Whitfield
Rd., following an illness of several weeks.
Mr. Barton, who served as Trustee during the terms of six
of Johns Hopkins University's eight presidents, was a partner in
the Baltimore law firm of Niles, Barton, Gans and Markell. He
was also Chancellor of the Episcopal Diocese of Maryland.
Services were held at 2:30 p.m. on Wednesday, March 7, in the
Chapel of the Church of the Redeemer. The Rt. Rev. Noble C.
Powell, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Maryland, officiated.
Great Loss To All
In a joint statement, Mr. Charles S. Garland, chairman of the
Board of Trustees of Johns Hopkins, and Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower,
University President, said: "Carlyle Barton's name and his personal contributions are carved indelibly in the history of The Johns
Hopkins University. He served for thirty-six years as a trustee,
and for nearly half that time he was President of the Board.
"In large measure, Hopkins today stands as a monument to
his wise leadership and his sympathetic understanding of the University's objectives. His colleagues on the Board of Trustees, the
administrative officers of the University, the faculty and the students, share the loss of a valued colleague and a warm friend."
Native Son
Mr. Barton, a native of Baltimore, received his Bachelor of
Arts degree from Johns Hopkins in 1906 and his Bachelor of Laws
degree from the University of Maryland in 1908. He was named to
the Board of Trustees of both the Johns Hopkins University and
Hospital in 1926.
He was elected chairman of the University Board of Trustees
in 1941, a position he held until his retirement in 1958. Even after
retirement Mr. Barton became a Trustee Emeritus of the University and took an active part in University affairs.
In 1958, the University honored Mr. Barton by awarding him
an honorary Doctor of Laws degree. Last November, the University
again paid tribute to Mr. Barton by laying the cornerstone of a
new building, named Barton Hall in his honor. It houses the University's Radiation Laboratory.
Contributions Noted
In Mr. Barton's years of service to Johns Hopkins, he helped
to widen the scope of the University's activities, while maintaining
its traditional place in American higher education. During the
years of World War II, immediately following Mr. Barton's appointment as President of the Board, the University took part in more
than 100 research projects of vital importance to the war effort.
In 1942 the Applied Physics Laboratory was founded to conduct
research. Shortly afterwards, in 1950, the University took over
operation of the School of Advanced International Studies in
Washington, D.C. In 1955, the Bologna Center of that school was
founded in Bologna, Italy.
Under Mr. Barton's leadership the Johns Hopkins Fund was
organized to raise funds for the University and Hospital. In recent
years numerous new buildings have been constructed both at the
Homewood Campus and at the Medical Institutions in East Baltimore.

Carlyle Barton, Sr., 76, retired chairman of the Board of
Trustees of the Johns Hopkins University and prominent Baltimore
attorney, died Monday morning, March 5 at his home, 16 Whitfield
Rd., following an illness of several weeks.
Mr. Barton, who served as Trustee during the terms of six

the Baltimore law firm of Niles, Barton, Gans and Markell. He
was also Chancellor of the Episcopal Diocese of Maryland.
Services were held at 2:30 p.m. on Wednesday, March 7, in the

Great Loss To All
In a joint statement, Mr. Charles S. Garland, chairman of the
Board of Trustees of Johns Hopkins, and Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower,
University President, said: "Carlyle Barton's name and his personal contributions are carved indelibly in the history of The Johns
Hopkins University. He served for thirty-six years as a trustee,
and for nearly half that time he was President of the Board.
"In large measure, Hopkins today stands as a monument to
his wise leadership and his sympathetic understanding of the University's objectives. His colleagues on the Board of Trustees, the
administrative officers of the University, the faculty and the students, share the loss of a valued colleague and a warm friend."
Native Son

Arts degree from Johns Hopkins in 1906 and his Bachelor of Laws
degree from the University of Maryland in 1908. He was named to

Hospital in 1926.
He was elected chairman of the University Board of Trustees
in 1941, a position he held until his retirement in 1958. Even after
retirement Mr. Barton became a Trustee Emeritus of the University and took an active part in University affairs.

an honorary Doctor of Laws degree. Last November, the University
again paid tribute to Mr. Barton by laying the cornerstone of a
new building, named Barton Hall in his honor. It houses the University's Radiation Laboratory.

its traditional place in American higher education. During the
years of World War II, immediately following Mr. Barton's appointment as President of the Board, the University took part in more
than 100 research projects of vital importance to the war effort.

research. Shortly afterwards, in 1950, the University took over
operation of the School of Advanced International Studies in
Washington, D.C. In 1955, the Bologna Center of that school was
founded in Bologna, Italy.
Under Mr. Barton's leadership the Johns Hopkins Fund was
organized to raise funds for the University and Hospital. In recent
years numerous new buildings have been constructed both at the
Homewood Campus and at the Medical Institutions in East Baltimore.

fourth clause of Article One of

clause can provide the law with
added power which may be vital

in the hands of a body which
emphasizes the system rather
than the individual, such a clause

exempts fraternities but not the
